description: This codelab teaches you how to containerize your web application and then host it on a GCP Kubernetes cluster with a custom domain name.

data.text: Introduction

NextJS is a popular framework to write react web applications. It has amazing features like Static Site Generation (SSG) and Server Side Rendering to make your web applications extremely fast and gives a boost to your SEO.  It comes correctly configured with all the bells and whistles needed to make your react application production-ready.

But deploying an app to cloud environment requires quite a lot of configuration and learning new things. This tutorial guides you on how you can deploy NextJS application to a Kubernetes Cluster on Google Cloud Platform and then point your custom domain name to it.
Prerequisites

items:
Domain Name 
In the last stage, we will pointing your custom domain name to your NextJS application hosted on Google Cloud Platform.  You can buy domain names from various sites like NameCheap, Or Domain.Google.

Google Cloud Account
You also need to have account created on Google Cloud Console with billing account setup. If you don't have one, you can create here.

data.message:
Running on Google Cloud may incur charges. 

Please make sure you follow instructions in last step to clean up your cluster after you are done.

data.text: Setup
Before we begin, we need below dependencies installed on your machine -
To confirm if your environment setup is correct, you can run simple version commands on your terminal as shown below
If any of the dependencies are missing, please use the links given to setup your environment properly.
Expected Output
At the end of this codelab, you would be able to get your web application hosted on your custom domain name and served by a kubernetes cluster hosted in GCP
Source Code
The entire source code is available here

meta.description: Contribute to nimahajan/codelab-nextjs-blog development by creating an account on GitHub.
meta.title: nimahajan/codelab-nextjs-blog

data.text: Let's get Started !
Create Simple NextJS Application
Let's create a simple NextJS application.

data.message:
Note 

If you are familiar with NextJS and already have a functional application, you can skip this step.

data.text: a. New NextJS Application
To create your first NextJS application,
This first instruction will take a few seconds to finish.  It downloads an existing demo example from NextJS Github directory into nextjs-blog directory.
b. Verify Your Application
To verify if everything is working correctly, run npm run dev and you can see the message like below -

data.code:
$ npm run dev

> nextjs-blog@0.1.0 dev /Users/nilesh/work/codelabs/helloworld/nextjs-blog
> next dev

ready - started server on http://localhost:3000
event - compiled successfully
event - build page: /next/dist/pages/_error
wait  - compiling...
event - compiled successfully
event - build page: /
wait  - compiling...
event - compiled successfully

data.text: If you visit, http://localhost:3000, you can see a demo page like below -

data.caption: Screenshot of our demo application page

data.text: Configure Google Cloud Project
Now, we need to create project in Google Cloud and set the zone to run our cluster into.
1. Create a project in Cloud Console
2. Enter a name for your Cloud project -  nextjs-blog and click Create.

data.message:
Important

Remember the project ID, shown under the Project name field. The project ID is important because it is used to identify your project to the Google Cloud tools

data.text: You will need this project ID many times. So you can set this project name as variable in terminal so that you don't make mistakes in next instructions.

data.code:
$ export GC_PROJECT_ID=nextjs-blog-292411
$ gcloud config set project ${GC_PROJECT_ID}

data.text: 3. Lastly, we need to set the zone to run the cluster into. List of available Google Compute Engine zones is here. Here, I have chosen us-central1-a. But you should generally choose one that is closest to where your most customers will be.
Build A Docker Image
Now comes the important part to make your react application cloud ready. To be able to deploy your application on Kubernetes cluster, you need a Dockerfile for your application.
So first, we will create a filed named Dockerfile in the root directory of your application and add the below contents to it -

Each command in the Dockerfile helps extend the image generated in previous stage. We start with a basic image FROM node:12 and then run our commands that copy our code into the image, install dependencies and then build the main application.  The last step exposes the port 3000 that our web application is using.
Now, lets start building our image with a Tag Name in below structure -
⏳ may take a few minutes as it downloads and build entire image.
Verification
To verify if the image and application in it is setup correctly, start the docker container
This should start your server and you can verify if your page is again visible on http://localhost:3000
If everything looks good, you can stop this docker container using -
Publish Docker Image on GCP
The docker image that we created in previous steps now should be pushed to Google Cloud Registry.
But before we do that, we need to enable Google Container Registry API on Google Cloud Console.
Now, we are ready to push this image to Google Container Registry.
Create a Kubernetes Cluster

Kubernetes is a portable, extensible, open-source platform for managing containerized applications and services. It makes it easy to create a cluster of multiple nodes and then manage their lifecycle.
Before you create one, you need to enable the Kubernetes Engine API for your project in Google Cloud. You can do that from the console.
Then choose correct project and click Enable as shown below -
Now, lets create a container cluster named nextjs-blog-test to deploy your web application:
Verification
Above command creates a 3 node cluster in a pool named default-pool. You can get information about this cluster using
The output looks something like this. -
Deploy the Docker to K8s Cluster
Once we have an operational cluster, we now need to deploy the docker image we created in earlier steps to our kubernetes cluster.
a. Create a deployment
Create a file named nextjs-blog-deployment.yaml on the root directory of our code and add the below content to it like below.
Note the Container Port 3000 on the last line. Now run the below command to make Kubernetes deploy your image to your cluster
b. Verification
You can get the details of your deployment and see them using below command -

data.code:
$ kubectl get deploy nextjs-blog
 
NAME          READY   UP-TO-DATE   AVAILABLE   AGE
nextjs-blog   1/1     1            1           59m

data.text: Creating a Load Balancer
There are 2 options to setup load balancer in front of your cluster nodes.

items: Use a Service, which creates a TCP Network Load Balancer that works with regional IP addresses.
Use an Ingress, which creates an HTTP(S) Load Balancer and supports global IP addresses.

data.text: But if we are exposing an HTTP(S) service hosted on GKE, HTTP(S) load balancing is the recommended method for load balancing. So we will choose option #2.
Since we wish to expose our service using our custom domain name, we need to reserve a static IP address. So let's create one.
a. Creating a Static IP Address
To create a global static IP Address -
To get the details of reserved IP address -
The Output looks like
The static IP Address shown here will be used to later when pointing domain name to your cluster.
b. Creating Service - Ingress and Backend
Now we need to create 2 services in kubernetes.
To create services, first create a next-blog-service.yaml with below content
It creates 2 services with configurations separated by ---.
Services are sets of Pods with a network endpoint that can be used for discovery and load balancing. Ingresses are collections of rules for routing external HTTP(S) traffic to Services.
Now to apply this configurations

data.message: ⏳ This step takes up to 10 mins.

data.text: c. Verification
You can check status using
Expected Output :

data.code:
NAME          HOSTS   ADDRESS            PORTS   AGE
nextjs-blog   *       <YOUR_GLOBAL_IP>   80      27m

data.text: Where <YOUR_GLOBAL_IP> will be the external global static IP that we created above in part a.
Or you can visit the console
You check if your site is properly up by visiting http://<YOUR_GLOBAL_IP>
Changing your DNS Settings
The global static IP address - <YOUR_GLOBAL_IP> that you created in previous state can now be used to change your DNS settings.
In our case, our domain is managed through domains.google.com. The record values should be like below -
It takes upto few minutes to few hours for the DNS changes to propagate, depending upon your domain name manager.
Verification
You can go to https://<your_domain_name> to see your application is hosted properly.
Clean Up

data.message: If you do not intent to keep the site up, you can follow below instructions to delete the cluster. Otherwise, you can skip to next steps.

data.text: 1. Delete Load Balancing Resources
2. Delete the allocation static global IP address
3. Delete the sample application
4. Delete Kubernetes Cluster
Conclusion
Setting up your web application in kubernetes cluster is quite straight forward.
There some extra configurations you can do to your cluster through the Cloud Console to make your cluster scale dynamically so that you can save some money.

title: How to deploy NextJS app to Kubernetes Cluster in GCP with Custom Domain?
